1.text:
Hi, I'm Rick Steves and I'm standing atop
one of the tiniest countries in Europe.

5.text:
Europe has a handful of these little "don't-blink-or-you'll-miss-'em"
lands:

9.text:
There's Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Vatican
City, and San Marino...

14.text:
we're about to visit them all. This time,
it's Little Europe.

51.text:
Medieval Europe was a patchwork of miniscule
dukedoms, princedoms, and feudal states. Modern-day

56.text:
Germany - about the size of Montana - was
fragmented into over 300 of these...each with

61.text:
its own petty ruler, weights and measures,
crown jewels, and curfew. These "countries"

66.text:
were only about as big as the distance a cannon
could fire from the town walls. And today,

71.text: only a handful of Europe's mini-nations survive.

75.text:
The world's smallest country comes with the
planet's biggest church. Another is famous

79.text:
for its casino and car races. A stone's throw
from the Adriatic Sea, the last of the independent

85.text:
hill towns still looks pretty formidable.
This castle-guarded principality is a remnant

90.text:
of Europe's once-mighty Holy Roman Empire.
And here, where Spain and France meet, another

95.text:
tiny country entertains shoppers and hikers
alike with the rugged beauty of the Pyrenees.

102.text:
Europe's "microstates" are scattered far and
wide. We'll start at Vatican City, drop by

107.text:
San Marino, hike up to Liechtenstein, speed
over to Monaco, and finish high in the Pyrenees

118.text:
Our first country is ruled by a man from another
country, it has less than 1,000 permanent

123.text:
residents, and its birthrate is zero. It's
visited by hordes of tourists daily, and it's

128.text:
the capital of a holy empire with more than
a billion subjects worldwide. Any guesses?

137.text:
The Vatican City. This is the smallest independent
country on earth. Even though it occupies

143.text:
less than a square mile - this country has
its own radio station, newspaper, post office,

146.text:
and a cute little train station. Along with
the grandest church on Earth, it has a massive

156.text:
museum. The Vatican is ruled - both politically
and religiously - by the pope.

164.text:
Vatican City is embedded in the city of Rome.
It's surrounded by a mighty medieval wall

175.text:
After the Roman Empire fell in the fifth century,
the city of Rome gradually came under control

179.text:
of the pope. In fact for centuries, the pope
was called the "King Pope." Little by little,

184.text:
the "King Pope" built his own empire. At its
peak around the 17th century, the "Papal States,"

190.text:
as they were called, encompassed much of the
Italian peninsula. When the modern nation

194.text:
of Italy was united, it absorbed most of the
Papal States, including the city of Rome.

202.text:
For sixty years the pope was holed up here,
behind the Vatican Walls. Finally, in 1929,

209.text:
the pope and Mussolini signed the Lateran
Treaty, establishing the Vatican as its own

214.text:
nation. The garden-like core of the country
- where serious administration takes place

221.text:
The Vatican "military" is made up of the Swiss
Guard. In 1506, the pope imported mercenaries

227.text:
from Switzerland, who were known for their
loyalty and courage. Today, about 100 Swiss

233.text:
soldiers still protect the pope, keep the
crush of tourists as orderly as possible...and

238.text:
wear the flamboyant Renaissance-style uniform
that tourists just love to photograph.

242.text:
The Vatican has its own postal service. Many
consider it to be more reliable than mailing

249.text:
things from across the street, in Italy...and
Vatican stamps are a fun souvenir.

255.text:
The Vatican is built on the memory and tomb
of the first pope, St. Peter. Piazza San Pietro

262.text:
sits on what was the site of a Roman racetrack.
Imagine chariots making their hairpin turns

269.text:
For added entertainment during the games,
Christians were executed here. In about 65

275.text:
A.D., the apostle Peter was crucified within
sight of this obelisk. His friends buried

280.text:
him in a humble graveyard atop what pagan
Romans called the Vatican Hill. For about

284.text:
250 years Christians worshipped quietly on
this spot. Then, when Emperor Constantine

289.text:
legalized Christianity in 313 A.D., a basilica
was built here, and this became the head of

296.text:
Twelve hundred years later, the original St.
Peter's was replaced by this, the most glorious

302.text:
church in all Christendom. Upon entering,
your first impression is: It's big...over

310.text:
600 feet long, bathed in glorious sunbeams.
It can accommodate thousands of worshippers.

317.text:
Near the entrance, Michelangelo's Pietà is
adored by pilgrims and tourists alike. Here

323.text:
the 25-year-old Michelangelo intends to make
the theological message very clear: Jesus

330.text:
- once alive but now dead - gave his life
for our salvation. The contrast provided by

335.text:
Mary's rough robe makes his body - even carved
in hard marble - seems soft and believable.

345.text:
The high altar, like so much of the art decorating
the Vatican, is a masterpiece by the great

349.text:
Baroque artist Bernini. With sunlight illuminating
its alabaster window - as if powering the

355.text:
Holy Spirit, it encrusts the legendary throne
of St. Peter with a starburst of Baroque praise.

363.text:
Directly above the altar which marks the tomb
of St. Peter, stands Bernini's bronze canopy,

367.text:
and above that Michelangelo's dome - taller
than a football field on end. The inscription

374.text:
declares, in Latin: Tu es Petrus..."You are
Peter and upon this rock I will build my church."

381.text:
This is the scriptural basis for the primacy
of Rome in the Catholic Church.

387.text:
A viewing perch gives travelers a close-up
look at those huge letters and a heavenly

394.text:
perspective into the church. From the rooftop
you can size up the dome you're about to climb.

401.text:
For a close look at Michelangelo's dome-within-a-dome
design, lean in as you climb 300 steps to

408.text:
The view from the top is unrivaled: both of
the city of Rome...and of the Vatican grounds.

414.text:
You can survey the entire country from this
lofty perch. The long rectangular building

418.text:
is the Vatican Museum with the adjacent Sistine
Chapel. These buildings and courtyards display

424.text: some of the greatest art of Western civilization.

428.text:
Over the centuries the popes have amassed
enough art to fill what many consider Europe's

432.text:
richest museum. Long halls are sumptuously
decorated with precious tapestries, frescoed

443.text:
The museum features art from every age. Its
exquisite painting gallery includes Raphael's

448.text:
much-loved painting of the Transfiguration.
Halls and courtyards are littered with ancient

455.text:
Greek masterpieces - like the Laocoön...so
inspirational to the great masters of the

464.text:
And the pope's apartments tell Christian history
- this is the battle in which Emperor Constantine

471.text:
was led by angels and a holy cross both to
a key military victory and to his own religious

478.text:
And these rooms celebrate pre-Christian philosophy.
Here Raphael paints the School of Athens...the

484.text:
who's who of ancient Greek intellectual heroes...many
painted with the features of Renaissance greats...Leonardo,

489.text:
Michelangelo...and a self-portrait of Raphael
in the black cap.

496.text:
But of course, we've just scratched the surface.
If you're pondering eternity, try covering

515.text:
On the opposite side of the Italian peninsula,
just a few miles inland from the Adriatic

519.text:
coast, is another tiny nation that's entirely
surrounded by Italy...San Marino.

527.text:
The Republic of San Marino brags it's the
world's oldest and smallest republic. It's

532.text:
remained sovereign through almost all its
1,700-year history. San Marino's isolated

538.text:
location has helped it maintain its independence.
The 24-square-mile country clings bravely

544.text:
to Monte Titano, in Italy's rugged Apennine
Mountains.

551.text:
A thousand years ago, Italy was made up of
dozens of independent little states like this.

559.text:
Over the centuries, virtually all of them
disappeared from the map. First, Europe's

564.text:
dominant royal families snatched up these
tiny territories, and added them to their

567.text:
vast kingdoms. Then, in the 19th century,
Italy's unification movement consolidated

572.text:
virtually the entire Italian peninsula into
the modern nation of Italy.

577.text:
San Marino survived because of Giuseppe Garibaldi.
A leader of the Italian unification movement,

583.text:
Garibaldi hid from his enemies here in San
Marino. In appreciation, Garibaldi allowed

592.text:
Perched above the old town are San Marino's
three characteristic castles. This trio of

597.text:
fortresses has done its part to keep San Marino
free and independent over the centuries. A

608.text:
Since the 1960s tourism has brought prosperity
- and along with it streets of tacky shops.

616.text:
About half the country's economy is based
on tourism.

623.text:
As in other tiny states, quirky laws and tax
regulations are used to stoke the economy.

628.text:
As sales tax is half what it is in surrounding
Italy, shoppers have long come here for the

636.text:
Several of Europe's tiny countries produce
their own stamps and coins - much sought after

643.text:
Rick: A stamp for my passport please.
Woman: Yes.

646.text: And for a fee, they'll even stamp your passport.

653.text:
The town's focal point is the long, balcony-like
Piazza della Libertà, with sweeping views

658.text:
over the realm. The statue depicting Liberty
- wearing a crown with the three castle towers

668.text:
- celebrates this country's passion for independence
and democracy.

673.text:
The Palazzo Pubblico, or "Palace of the People,"
is guarded by some of San Marino's tiny security

681.text:
A modest stairway leads to the room from where
the country is governed. Paintings remind

689.text:
legislators of its long history and the saint
who's considered the father of this little

697.text:
In about the year 300, Marino, a stone cutter
from present-day Croatia, fled persecution

702.text:
from the Roman Emperor. He found refuge here,
on Monte Titano and decided to stay and help

707.text:
the community of other fleeing Christians.
He was made a saint for his efforts, and remains

711.text: the patron saint of this country to this day.

717.text:
From this lofty perch, San Marino's soldiers
have defended their homeland - with the latest

723.text:
in military technology. Ever since a key victory
back in the 15th century, the crossbowmen

731.text: of San Marino have been a part of state celebrations.

734.text:
Traditionally, this forced the marksmen to
stay sharp and keep their crossbows in good

738.text:
working order. While today it's mostly an
excuse to show off for tourists, their sport

743.text:
is still taken seriously. The marksmen hit
their target with armor-piercing force - illustrating

752.text:
the pride of nation with a long if not mighty
heritage.

761.text:
As if celebrating their bulls-eyes, the San
Marino Crossbowman Federation enlivens their

766.text: mountain top republic with traditional fanfare.

789.text:
San Marino takes you back to the age of city
states, an era of pageantry, pride and fierce

794.text:
independence. Further north lays another pint
sized country that is tucked away not on a

811.text: hill - but in the mighty Alps.

815.text:
Two centuries ago, there were dozens of independent
states in German-speaking Europe. Today, there

819.text:
are only four: Germany, Austria, Switzerland...and
Liechtenstein.

828.text:
Nestled between Switzerland and Austria, the
Principality of Liechtenstein is defined by

833.text:
the mighty Alps to the east, the baby Rhine
River to the west, and a stout fortress protecting

841.text:
the mouth of its valley to the south. This
quirky remnant of medieval feudal politics

845.text:
is just about 62 square miles. It is truly
land-locked, without a seaport, or even an

860.text:
Liechtensteiners - who number about 35,000
- speak German, are mostly Catholic, and have

864.text:
a stubborn independent streak. Women weren't
given the vote until 1984.

872.text:
The country's made up of 11 villages. The
village of Triesenberg, high above the valley,

877.text:
gathers around its onion-domed church, which
recalls the settlers who arrived here centuries

882.text: ago from the western part of Switzerland.

886.text:
The town of Vaduz sits on the valley floor.
While it has only 5,000 people, it's the country's

895.text:
capital. Its pedestrianized main drag is lined
with modern art and hotels bordering a district

908.text:
Historically Europe's tiny countries have
offered businesses special tax and accounting

912.text:
incentives. For a place with such a small
population, Liechtenstein has a lot of businesses.

918.text:
Many European companies locate here to take
advantage of its low taxes.

924.text:
And that's how the Prince of Liechtenstein,
whose castle is perched above his domain,

928.text:
likes it. The billionaire prince, who looks
down on his 6-by-12-mile country, wields more

933.text:
real political power in his realm than any
other European royalty.

939.text:
The national museum tells the story of the
prince and his country. Their family crest

945.text:
dates to the Middle Ages, when the Liechtenstein
family was close friends with the Habsburg

949.text:
family, who ruled the Holy Roman Empire. The
Liechtenstein family purchased this piece

956.text:
of real estate from the Holy Roman Emperor.
In 1719, the domain was granted principality

961.text:
status - answering only to the Emperor. The
Liechtenstein princes - who lived near Vienna

967.text:
- saw their new country merely as a status
symbol, and didn't even bother to visit for

972.text:
decades. In fact, it wasn't until the 20th
century that the first Liechtenstein prince

980.text:
In 1806, during the Napoleonic age, Liechtenstein's
obligations to the Habsburg Emperor disappeared

986.text:
and the country was granted true independence.
Later, after World War I, tough times forced

992.text:
the principality to enter into an economic
union with Switzerland.

997.text:
To this day Liechtenstein enjoys a close working
relationship with its Swiss neighbors.

1002.text:
And like Switzerland, a big part of its modern
economy is tourism and sports - hosting visitors

1008.text:
enjoying its dramatic natural beauty. Ski
lifts, busy both winter and summer, take nature

1014.text:
lovers to the dizzying ridge that serves as
the border with Austria. Even in little little

1021.text:
Liechtenstein...the views are big and the
hiking possibilities go on and on.

1035.text:
On the Mediterranean Sea, basking between
the French and Italian Rivieras, the Principality

1039.text:
of Monaco barely fits on its one square mile
of territory.

1044.text:
Of its 30,000 residents, less than 10,000
are true Monegasques, as locals are called.

1049.text:
Many of the rest call Monaco home because
there's no income tax. Despite over development,

1056.text:
high prices, and mobs of tourists, a visit
here is a Riviera must.

1063.text:
And Monaco is a work in progress. The district
of Fontvieille was reclaimed from the sea.

1068.text:
It bristles with luxury high-rise condos.
The breakwater - constructed elsewhere and

1074.text:
towed in - enables cruise ships to dock. And
cars still race, as they have since 1929,

1081.text:
around the principality in one of the world's
most famous auto races, the Grand Prix of

1091.text:
The miniscule principality has always been
tiny. But it used to be less tiny. In the

1095.text:
1860s it lost most of its territory to France.
But the prince built a casino and managed

1100.text:
to connect his domain to the rest of the Riviera
with a new road and a train line.

1105.text:
Humble Monaco was suddenly on the Grand Tour
map - the place for the vacationing aristocracy

1110.text:
to play. Today, the people of Monaco have
one of the world's highest per-capita incomes,

1116.text:
with plush apartments to match. Its famous
casino allows the wealthy to enjoy losing

1127.text:
If Monaco is a business; the prince is its
CEO. While the casino generates only a small

1134.text:
part of the state's revenue, its many banks
- which provide an attractive way to protect

1139.text:
your money from the taxman - earn much more.
There is no income tax here, but the prince

1144.text:
collects plenty of money in value-added taxes,
real estate taxes and corporate taxes.

1150.text:
Nearly all of Monaco's sights are packed in
a Cinderella neighborhood atop its fortified

1154.text:
hill. Its impressive aquarium, which proudly
crowns the cliff like a palace, was directed

1162.text:
A medieval castle sat where Monaco's palace
sits today. The palace square features a statue

1168.text:
of François Grimaldi, a renegade Italian
who captured Monaco disguised as a monk in

1177.text:
This first ruler of Monaco established the
dynasty that still rules the principality.

1182.text:
Today, over 700 years later, the current prince
is his direct descendant.

1187.text:
Palace guards protect the ruling Grimaldi
family 24/7 and they change with the pageantry

1192.text:
of an important nation. Every day at about
noon tourists pack the square to witness the

1197.text: spectacle in this improbable little princedom.

1211.text:
Our final stop is Andorra - the biggest of
these midget countries. If you're keeping

1216.text:
track, here's a rundown on Europe's tiny derby
showing each of these countries' relative

1222.text:
The Vatican is the big little winner. Then
comes Monaco, San Marino, Liechtenstein and

1229.text:
finally, Andorra. Luxemburg is Europe's next
smallest country. Small as it is, it would

1236.text:
easily fit all five microstates within its
borders.

1244.text:
Andorra sits high in the craggy Pyrenees Mountains,
as if hiding out between Spain and France.

1249.text:
With 180 square miles and about 75,000 people,
it's the largest of Europe's micro-countries.

1259.text:
The country has a long history. In their national
anthem, Andorrans sing of Charlemagne rescuing

1264.text:
their land from the Moors back in 803. In
the 13th century Spanish and French nobles

1269.text:
married. They agreed that the principality
would be neither Spanish nor French. This

1274.text:
unique feudal arrangement survives today.
And - while they have co-princes: one happens

1279.text:
to be the president of France and the other
a bishop from Spain - locals stress that their

1288.text:
Until little more than a generation ago, Andorra
was an impoverished and isolated backwater.

1293.text:
Churches date back to the 12th and 13th centuries.
Their stony Romanesque bell towers stand strong

1304.text:
That same local stone is used today as a building
boom illustrates how, lately, the principality

1308.text:
has flourished. Since World War II the population
has increased tenfold. Recently Andorrans

1317.text:
The mountains that kept the principality both
isolated and poor are now a source of its

1322.text:
prosperity. Hiking and skiing are understandably
big business here.

1328.text:
And Andorra employs those special economic
weapons so popular among Europe's little states:

1334.text:
easy-going banking, duty-free shopping, and
low, low taxes. It's morphed from a rough

1339.text:
and tumble smuggler's haven to a high-tech,
high-altitude shopper's haven - famous for

1347.text:
While Andorrans speak Catalan - and have an
affinity for the Spanish region of Catalunya

1351.text:
and Barcelona - the commercial environment
here is international as can be.

1356.text:
The country's capital and dominant city, Andorra
la Vella, is a mostly modern town with the

1361.text:
charm of a giant shopping mall. While most
know this place for its shops and for what

1367.text:
locals claim is the biggest spa in Europe,
pockets of Old World charm do hide out in

1379.text:
The Casa de la Vall is the country's parliament
building. A private residence back in the

1384.text:
16th century, today it houses Andorra's claustrophobic
parliament chamber. It has 28 seats - that's

1391.text:
four representatives for each of the seven
parishes - with portraits of the current co-princes

1402.text:
While a humble reminder of a simple past,
Andorrans still look to this building for

1406.text:
leadership as their country builds an ever
better life for its citizens.

1411.text:
So, what do Andorra and the rest of Europe's
little countries have in common? Most of them

1415.text:
are high in the mountains or some other hard-to-reach
terrain. Many offer low or no taxes, which

1421.text:
encourage businesses and individuals from
other countries to come and support the local

1425.text:
economy. Each one has survived centuries of
warfare, treaties, and reshaped borders - usually

1431.text:
thanks to a combination of diplomatic skill
and luck. All of them get by on the coattails

1436.text:
of larger nations. And they're small and easy
to overlook, so they can fall through the

1442.text:
cracks without being noticed by the next big
tyrant.

1449.text:
Most important, all of them are sustained
by an unwavering national pride in their unlikely

1455.text:
yet enduring independence. Thanks for joining
us. I'm Rick Steves. Until next time, keep

...Croatia fled persecution from the Emperor
Dioclesian...

For a place with such a small population,
